## Post‑licensure safety monitoring – how we keep watching a vaccine after it’s on the market Once a pediatric vaccine (e.g., PCV13, MMR, DTaP, HPV, COVID‑19 mRNA) has received regulatory approval and is being given to millions of children, a **multilayered safety‑surveillance system** continues to collect data, look for unexpected problems, and act on them quickly. The system is built on three complementary pillars: | **Pillar** | **What it does** | **Key tools & examples** | **What it can detect** | |------------|------------------|--------------------------|------------------------| | **1. Passive (spontaneous) reporting** | Anyone—parents, clinicians, vaccine manufacturers, patients—can voluntarily submit an adverse‑event report. | • **VAERS** (U.S.) – Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System
• **Yellow Card Scheme** (U.K.)
• **EudraVigilance** (EU)
• **VigiBase** (WHO global database) | Rare, unexpected events that may not have been seen in trials (e.g., Guillain‑Barré syndrome after influenza vaccine). | | **2. Active (structured) surveillance** | Pre‑defined cohorts are followed prospectively; data are extracted from electronic health records, insurance claims, or dedicated study sites. | • **Vaccine Safety Datalink (VSD)** – > 25 U.S. health‑maintenance organizations covering > 12 million people.
• **CDC’s ** **Clinical Immunization Safety Assessment (CISA)** network – expert case‑review centers.
• **Post‑Authorization Safety Studies (PASS)** required by regulators (EU, FDA, Health Canada).
• **Sentinel System** (U.S. FDA) – real‑time claims data on > 100 million patients. | • Relative risk of specific outcomes (e.g., febrile seizures after DTaP) within a few days of vaccination.
• Signals that are too uncommon for detection in Phase III (≈1 per 100 000‑1 per 1 000 000). | | **3. • **Rapid Cycle Analysis (RCA)** – weekly statistical scans of VSD data for pre‑specified outcomes.
